q: What is malaria?
a: Malaria is a serious infection spread by mosquitoes. If not diagnosed and treated quickly, it can be fatal.

q: How can I check if I'm at risk of malaria?
a: Malaria is caused by being bitten by an infected mosquito. Certain parts of the world have a high risk of malaria. Learn more about specific countries on the Travel Health Pro website.

q: What steps can I take to avoid malaria?
a: If you're traveling to an area where malaria is found, seek advice from a medical professional. They may prescribe antimalarial tablets and provide guidance on preventing mosquito bites.

q: Who is most at risk of getting seriously ill from malaria?
a: Pregnant women, young children, people over 65, those with weak immune systems or no spleen are at higher risk. Even if traveling to low-risk areas, they may still be prescribed antimalarial medicine.

q: What are the symptoms of malaria?
a: Symptoms of malaria include high temperature, sweats and chills, headaches, confusion, fatigue, vomiting, muscle pains, yellowing of the skin or eyes, and respiratory issues. Symptoms may appear within 7 to 18 days after being bitten by an infected mosquito.

q: What should I do if I suspect I have malaria?
a: If you have traveled to a malaria-infected country and experience symptoms, seek an urgent GP appointment or call NHS 111 for assistance. Inform anyone you traveled with to do the same.

q: How is malaria treated?
a: Malaria is treated with antimalarial medicines. In some cases, hospitalization for specialist care may be necessary. Repeat treatments may be required if the infection returns.

q: What are the symptoms of malaria?
a: Symptoms of malaria include high temperature, sweats and chills, headaches, feeling confused, fatigue, vomiting, muscle pains, yellow skin or whites of the eyes, sore throat, cough, and difficulty breathing.

q: How can I avoid getting malaria?
a: If you're traveling to an area where malaria is found, it's best to get advice from a healthcare professional before you go. You may be prescribed antimalarial tablets and advised on precautionary measures such as using insect repellent, sleeping under treated mosquito nets, and wearing protective clothing.

q: Who is most at risk of getting seriously ill from malaria?
a: Pregnant women, young children, people aged over 65, individuals with a weak immune system, and those without a spleen are at higher risk of getting seriously ill from malaria.

q: What should I do if I have traveled to a country where malaria is found and have symptoms of malaria?
a: If you have traveled to a malaria-endemic country and have symptoms of malaria, it is important to seek urgent medical advice. You can ask for an urgent GP appointment or get help from NHS 111.

q: Are there any treatments available for malaria?
a: Malaria is treated with antimalarial medicines. In some cases, hospitalization may be required for specialist care and treatment. If the disease recurs, it will need to be treated again.

q: How long does it take for malaria symptoms to appear after being bitten by an infected mosquito?
a: Malaria symptoms usually appear between 7 and 18 days after being bitten by an infected mosquito. However, in some cases, symptoms may not occur for months or even years after travel.

q: Can malaria be fatal if left untreated?
a: Yes, malaria can be a serious and potentially fatal infection if not diagnosed and treated quickly.

q: Where is malaria commonly found in the world?
a: Malaria is common in tropical regions, including large areas of Africa, Asia, Central and South America, the Dominican Republic, Haiti, parts of the Middle East, and some Pacific islands. However, it is not found in the UK.

q: When should I seek medical advice if I have malaria symptoms while traveling?
a: If you have malaria symptoms while traveling, it is important to seek medical advice promptly. You can call NHS 111 or get help online.

q: Can malaria come back after treatment?
a: Yes, malaria can sometimes come back after treatment, and it will need to be treated again if this happens.
